title: 104_s598
content: The Act titled "Tobacco Consumption Reduction and Health Improvement Act of 1995" increases taxes on tobacco products. The "Tobacco Consumption Reduction and Health Improvement Act of 1995" increases taxes on cigars, with amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The tax rate on cigars is raised to $5.8125 per thousand, and for large cigars weighing over 3 pounds per thousand, a tax of 65.875% of the selling price, not exceeding $155 per thousand, is imposed. The tax rates on cigarettes are increased under the "Tobacco Consumption Reduction and Health Improvement Act of 1995". The tax on cigarettes is raised to $62 per thousand, and for cigarette papers, the tax is increased to $130.20 per thousand. The tax rates on cigarette papers, cigarette tubes, and snuff are increased under the "Tobacco Consumption Reduction and Health Improvement Act of 1995". The tax on cigarette papers is raised to 3.875 cents, on cigarette tubes to 7.75 cents, and on snuff is amended. The tax rates on smokeless tobacco products are increased under the "Tobacco Consumption Reduction and Health Improvement Act of 1995". The tax on chewing tobacco is raised to 62 cents, on pipe tobacco to $3.4875, and on snuff to $1.86. The amendments made by the "Tobacco Consumption Reduction and Health Improvement Act of 1995" increase tax rates on smokeless tobacco products, including raising the tax on pipe tobacco to $3.4875. The effective date for these changes is after December 31, 1995. The "Tobacco Consumption Reduction and Health Improvement Act of 1995" raised taxes on smokeless tobacco products, including pipe tobacco to $3.4875. Additionally, roll-your-own tobacco is subject to a tax of $1.86 per pound in the United States. The tax amendments include adding roll-your-own tobacco to the list of taxed products, alongside pipe tobacco. The tax amendments include adding roll-your-own tobacco to the list of taxed products, alongside pipe tobacco. The amendment allows a person to produce cigars, cigarettes, smokeless tobacco, pipe tobacco, or roll-your-own tobacco for personal consumption. The chapter heading for chapter 52 of the Code is amended accordingly. The chapter heading for chapter 52 of the Code is amended to include roll-your-own tobacco as a taxed product. The table of chapters for subtitle E is updated to reflect this change. Chapter 52 of the Code is amended to include roll-your-own tobacco as a taxed product, with amendments effective for tobacco removed after December 31, 1995. Before January 1, 1996, a manufacturer of roll-your-own tobacco or importer of tobacco products can continue their business by submitting an application under chapter 52 of the Code. All provisions of chapter 52 apply to the applicant until final action is taken on the application. On cigars, cigarettes, cigarette paper, cigarette tubes, snuff, chewing tobacco, and pipe tobacco manufactured in or imported into the United States before January 1, 1996, held for sale, taxes will be imposed. Taxes are imposed on small and large cigars, small and large cigarettes based on weight and price. Cigarettes over 6.5 inches taxed based on length, with each 2.75 inches counted as one cigarette. Cigarette papers over 6.5 inches taxed similarly. On cigarette tubes, 6.25 cents for each 50 tubes or fractional part thereof; for tubes over 6.5 inches, each 2.75 inches is counted as one tube. Snuff is taxed at $1.50 per pound and a proportionate tax on fractional parts. Chewing tobacco is taxed at 50 cents. (H) Chewing tobacco is taxed at 50 cents per pound, while pipe tobacco is taxed at $2.8125 per pound. Liability for the tax applies to individuals holding these products on January 1, 1996. The tax imposed on cigars, cigarettes, and other tobacco products is due and payable on February 15, 1996, following the rates specified for each product. The tax on cigars, cigarettes, and other tobacco products is due on February 15, 1996, at specified rates. Terms like cigar, cigarette, snuff, and pipe tobacco are defined according to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Retail stocks are exempt from these taxes. The tax on cigars, cigarettes, cigarette paper, tubes, snuff, chewing tobacco, and pipe tobacco is exempt for retail stocks held on January 1, 1996. Foreign trade zones are also exempt from federal taxes and customs duties on these tobacco products. Cigars, cigarettes, cigarette paper, tubes, snuff, chewing tobacco, and pipe tobacco are exempt from federal taxes and customs duties if they are entered into the customs territory of the United States from a foreign trade zone after January 1, 1996. Cigars, cigarettes, cigarette paper, tubes, snuff, chewing tobacco, and pipe tobacco subject to tax if entered into the US from a foreign trade zone after January 1, 1996. Cigars, cigarettes, cigarette paper, tubes, snuff, chewing tobacco, and pipe tobacco are treated as being held for sale on January 1, 1996. A trust fund is established under the Internal Revenue Code for these products. A trust fund is established under the Internal Revenue Code for tobacco products. The Tobacco Conversion Trust Fund is created in the Treasury, funded by a percentage of revenue increases from tobacco-related amendments. The Tobacco Conversion Trust Fund, created in the Treasury, is funded by revenue increases from tobacco-related amendments. Amounts in the Trust Fund are available for the Secretary of Agriculture to provide assistance to farmers transitioning from tobacco to other crops and supporting economic diversification plans for communities and individuals in the tobacco industry. The Tobacco Conversion Trust Fund, funded by tobacco-related revenue increases, supports economic diversification plans for communities and individuals in the tobacco industry. Assistance may include government purchase of tobacco allotments to retire them from production. The Tobacco Conversion Trust Fund, supported by tobacco-related revenue increases, aids in economic diversification for communities and individuals in the tobacco industry by potentially purchasing tobacco allotments to retire them from production.
